revision.text: {{also|i-am}} ==Esperanto== ===Etymology=== {{term|i-|lang=eo||indeterminate [[:Category:Esperanto correlatives|correlative]] prefix}} + {{term|-am|lang=eo||correlative suffix of time}} ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|/ˈi.am/|lang=eo}} ===Adverb=== {{head|eo|correlative}} # [[sometime]], [[ever]] (indeterminate correlative of time) # [[once]] #* '''2000''', Antoine de Saint Exupéry, ''[http://i-espero.info/files/elibroj/eo%20-%20saint-exupery,%20antoine%20de%20-%20la%20eta%20princo.pdf La Eta Princo]'', translated by Pierre Delaire from the French #*: ''Iam, kiam mi estis sesjara, mi vidis belegan bildon en iu libro pri la praarbaro, titolita "Travivitaj rakontoj".'' #*:: Once, when I was six years old, I saw a magnificent picture in some book, titled "True Stories." ====Derived terms==== * {{l|eo|iam ajn|gloss=[[anytime]]}} * {{l|eo|iama}} {{eo BRO|1}} {{eo GCSE|0}} [[Category:Esperanto adverbs]] [[Category:Esperanto correlatives]] ---- ==Latin== ===Etymology=== From {{etyl|ine-pro|la}} {{term/t|ine-pro|*yē||already}}. Cognate with {{etyl|got|-}} {{term|𐌾𐌰||tr=ja|lang=got}}, {{term|𐌾𐌰𐌹||yes|tr=jai|lang=got}}, {{etyl|goh|-}} {{term|ja|ja, jā|yes|tr={{etyl|de|-}} {{term|ja|lang=de}}|lang=goh}}, {{etyl|ang|-}} {{term|gea|ġēa|yea, yes|tr={{etyl|en|-}} {{term|yea|lang=en}}|lang=ang}}. More at {{l|en|yes}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{a|Classical}} {{IPA|/ˈjam/|lang=la}} * {{audio|la-cls-iam.ogg|Audio (Classical)}} ===Adverb=== {{la-adv||iam|-}} # [[already]] #: ''Birota '''iam''' refecta est.'' #:: The bicycle has '''already''' been repaired. # [[now]] #* [[w:Curculio (play)|Curculio]] by [[w:Plautus|Plautus]], 5,3,5: #*: CAPPADOX: '''Iam iam''' faciam ut iusseris.[http://www.thelatinlibrary.com/plautus/curculio.shtml Latin] #*:: CAPPADOX: '''Here''', '''here''', I’ll do as you say![http://artemis.austincollege.edu/acad/cml/rcape/comedy/5-3.html English] # [[anymore]] ====Usage notes==== {{term|iam|Iam|lang=la}} means, generally, “at some point previous” or “since some point previous”. In English, {{term|already}}, the most common translation, is used only to emphasize that this point might have been expected to be later, whereas {{term|now}} is used to emphasize that the statement was once false, even when the statement refers to a point in the past or future. {{term|iam|Iam|lang=la}} is used to express either. (Likewise, the most common Latin word for {{term|now}}, {{term|nunc|lang=la}}, denotes only the literal present moment.) Also, where {{term|iam|lang=la}} means {{term|now}}, it is often used in negative sentences, in which the most common English construction uses {{term|anymore}}. ====Derived terms==== * [[etiam]] * [[iamdudum]] * [[non iam]] * [[iam pridem]] ====Descendants==== {{top2}} * Catalan: {{l|ca|ja}} * Esperanto: {{l|eo|jam}} * French: {{l|fr|jà}} * Basque: {{l|eu|ia}} {{mid2}} * Italian: {{l|it|già}} * Portuguese: {{l|pt|já}} * Spanish: {{l|es|ya}} {{bottom}} ====References==== [[Category:la:Time]] ---- ==Portuguese== ===Pronunciation=== * {{a|PT}} {{IPA|/ˈiɐ̃w̃/|lang=pt}} ===Verb=== {{pt-verb form}} # {{pt-verb form of|ir||indicative|imperfect|plural|third}} [[af:iam]] [[br:iam]] [[cs:iam]] [[el:iam]] [[fr:iam]] [[ko:iam]] [[io:iam]] [[la:iam]] [[lt:iam]] [[mg:iam]] [[nl:iam]] [[ja:iam]] [[no:iam]] [[pl:iam]] [[pt:iam]] [[ru:iam]] [[sk:iam]] [[fi:iam]] [[zh:iam]]
